segments.text: It was a designated area where a division size unit could go in and train.
Flinders Range it was called.
So we trained there and after that phase we were sent up to New Guinea.
Yeah, that would make sense.
But again, we were put into New Guinea at Oro Bay and still didn't have a mission.
Is that December 43?
That was December 43.
I guess we got there in January.
Okay, but let's not leave Australia yet.
I'd like to ask a couple of questions.
All right.
I'd like to know about the relations between our allies, between the Australians, who are our allies, and the United States.
First on the military level, did you train with the military?
And then on the people level, what were your relations with the civilians?
Well, that was another good experience.
I guess I sound like to you that I never had any bad experiences.
Maybe I just put those in the back of my mind.
But as I told you earlier, in my 30 years in the Army, I never had a bad job.
I'm only one son of a bitch boss.
And that's true.
The Australians were magnificent.
They were delighted to see us come.
The threat of the Japanese was very real.
And they, today,
We'll credit General MacArthur and his strategy and his troops with saving Australia from probably a devastating invasion by the Japanese.
General MacArthur's as big a hero as Australia has from anywhere, including Australia, Australians.
But now remember that when we got there,
the vast bulk of the Australian Army was committed to Europe, actually to Africa.
And so there weren't many Australian troops that we went into combat with.
But of course we had the Army facilities there and support, and we had some of the troops
go into the islands with us.
The people, and they were magnificent soldiers.
They were good soldiers.
They were magnificent soldiers.
Well-trained?
Well-trained, and of course, in war, it's the motivation and the determination by the man and his team and his units and so forth that win.
Training's important to it, but it's the will.
Easy to work with.
And they had the will, and there's no doubt about it.
Was it easy to work with them?
Oh, yes.
Oh, yes.
No problems with communications or anything?
No, as a matter of fact, my comment and feeling was that the Australians were much more like Texans in their outlook and feelings and so forth than they were British.
In other words, they've been very close allies of the British during all their years of existence.
They were members of the Commonwealth and so forth.
But really, they remind you very much of Texans, the one that I observed came to notice.
In what way?
They're very open.
They're very frank.
They're a little bit, I don't know, they're a little bit braggadocious.
There are just several things about them that reminded me of that, you know, we had a lot more in common than they had in common with the British.
And I say Texan because we're different, I think, than the rest, don't you?
Now that you've been down here.
You know, and the way we talk and our openness and frankness, sometimes it's called crudeness, depending on who's observing it and under what circumstances.
So you had excellent relations with the armed
No problem as far as any, throughout the war, no problems that you can remember?
No episodes?
Oh, I didn't.
I know there were episodes.
I, you know, individual episodes.
But that's going to happen Saturday night in Coffman.
Sure.
Now, we have never experienced this on a large scale, but here was a case where the boys' and girls' pictures
It was always real.
Here were all these Yankees coming into Australia and most of the soldiers were gone to Europe, you know.
So that created some frictions.

But I must say that all the people in Australia, the civilians, whether they were government officials or heads of families or girls, and there weren't many young men available by God except in uniform.
They were just like we were.
They were just drafting everybody that was
They were all very nice to us, and it wasn't just the girls falling for the Yanks.
It was that we were just all very congenial.
I know you read, I'm sure, that somebody's always going to write about the boy and girl situation.
Any major problems as far as you were concerned with the boy and girl situation?
In fact, we were very busy in Australia.
I never really came to know Australian civilians of any kind until I was one of the lucky few that got a leave back from the islands a year later to go to Sydney on two weeks leave, recreation leave.
And that's when I really, the only time that I, and it turned out I didn't get transportation back for another week, I guess it was.
And Sydney's the main city.
And that's the only time that I really was exposed to civilians.
But there I was.
I did get to know some of them.
20 years later, 25 years later, the Australians put a few troops
In Vietnam?
Yes.
Could you compare the troops in the 40s with those that they put in in the 1960s?
Only by reputation, because I was in Vietnam a year and a half, and I spent all of that time with the 1st Cavalry Division.
And I never was close to the Australian units in there.
But they were highly regarded.
very highly regarded.
They had a brigade in there, as I recall, a reinforced brigade, which is relatively small, or maybe they called it a regiment.
But our troops respected them.
They're very fine and courageous soldiers, and they're well trained.
Now, of course, the difference is that
To the best of my knowledge, Australia did not mobilize for the Vietnam War.
So we were looking at the career soldiers, the professionals, rather than the World War II, everybody's in it.
Now, the difference mainly is in age, average age.
The average age of our World War II soldier was, I think, 20 and a half.
every day looking at everybody in the Army, 21 maybe.
Vietnam, it was just a little bit more, the average.
That means that although we had more senior in years officers in grade and non-commissioned officers, still your buck was those youngsters.
And remember, and I believe I'm correct, that we could, we drafted a
drafted younger in Vietnam in World War II.
Okay, then let's continue.
You moved on to New Guinea in January of 1945 or 44.
This had been a major front.
New Guinea, at that time, they had won the big battle for
What was the name of the mountain?
That the Japanese were threatening to take that lower coast of New Guinea, which would have been very dangerous for the Australians.
That battle was won.
And so MacArthur was facing on up, figuring out how he was going to leapfrog through the island.
And we sat there at New Guinea, really,
until we went to the Admiralty Islands.
The only mission we had other than training for those few weeks was, well actually a few months, was supporting the Marines on New Britain.
And we'd actually load our trucks and our men with resupplies, ammunition mainly, and security troops onto Navy ships to go up and
resupply the Marines in New Britain.

And then one day, we got our first mission, and that was to go into the Admiralty Islands and seize Maumotiair Field, landing on Los Negros Island, and then expanding into Manus, the bigger island, the outlying islands, and cleaning them out of there.
Now the Admiralty Island, you might recall, was just above New Britain, and that's sort of outflanking New Britain.
New Britain had been a major base for the Japanese.
And once we got in there, we then were busy from there on.
We were one invasion after another.
After we cleaned up there, then we went on up to Okay, when did you land there?
We landed there in March March of 44.
What were your feelings about going into combat?
Probably typical.
I guess the main feeling was, are we going to be good enough to get this done quickly and successfully?
And, of course, you always, aside from winning, or in addition to winning, you always want to keep the casualties low.
And I must say that...
While General MacArthur's influence was not direct, I do credit him by virtue of the strategies he followed and the targets he selected for invasion, the objectives he selected.
I've always credited him with keeping casualties to a minimum in the Pacific.
Now, that wasn't all for humanistic reasons.
The fact was that he was second
in line for replacements.
And if he took severe casualties, he didn't know when he might get them replaced.
So it was a two-sided consideration.
Did you ever have an opportunity to meet the general?
I never shook his hand.
I saw him several times because he was

he was uh that was a kind of a war that the general couldn't visit every outfit every week but when we uh because you know we were all over the map but uh when he committed us to an operation he was always there the day we landed or the day after i'll never forget you've seen the

famous photograph of General MacArthur coming ashore and saying, I have returned, and it was on Lady Island, and I did not see that coming ashore, but I saw him the next morning, and it was rather interesting how that happened.
I don't know, there were four divisions in the assault in that landing on Lady.
Our first cavalry division was the Northern

was the capital city of Tacloban of the Isle of the Lady I don't know how many landing craft the large ones you know that put their ramps down and the vehicles come off LSTs I don't know how many we had in that line and that was a beautiful beach but for some reason we hit a sandbar about
100 feet from shore, and they could not get that ship over that sandbar.
All the rest of them, right on the right, right on the left, were right up hugging the beach.
The squadron commander was aboard that ship, and he would not replace it anywhere else.
Well, I guess he couldn't.
There was no other place to put it.
So we unloaded that ship through that water.
Every vehicle, every gun,
Every soldier went through that blame.
How deep was it?
Well, it was about chest deep to a man at the average tide, the high tide.
But anyway, it took us all night to get our ship unloaded.
The first thing we got out, of course, were our guns, and they went into action, the 105 howitzers.
And next morning, having just completed this,
my unit.
I was executive officer, number two, second in command of that battalion.
The battalion command went forward with it, and I unloaded the ship, and we'd sent all the vehicles forward in just a few hundred yards in there, and so I decided I was going to walk.
Hadn't slept a wink all night, and there was a trail there, a little road that went down there.
Well, I just

turned off the beach walking up that road and I heard the two jeep's horns all of a sudden sounding look around and here was Joe MacArthur and his staff coming in to take a look at what was being done and I had the greatest admiration and respect for him but I I really wasn't impressed I was so dang tired I could hardly walk down that road but anyway typically he went on

forward, and every time he visited our division, our division commander would be nervous because General MacArthur wanted to be right up there, right up there where the front forward shooting's going on, you know, and you always worry about, he didn't, but the responsible commander, whether it be the division commander and the regimental commander and right on down were very much concerned with him, but he was

good in that regard of having absolutely no regard for his personal safety, which is to some extent a disregard for the comfort of his subordinates, but he let the men know that he was a part of that war.
I guess that's the closest I was ever to him, but he didn't have to be present to be respected because he had a way of
projecting his command influence right down to the last soldier, I thought.
Let's go back to your very first invasion.
Tell me about it.
How'd it go?
Well, it went very successfully.
We did have a lot of casualties in the first squadron.
See, the Calvary designation is troop instead of company.
squadron instead of battalion, and then your regiment terms, the rest of them were the same.
The reinforced squadron went in initially, and before the next squadron landed, they took very heavy cavalry, but they just really Right on the beach?
No, they got off the beach.
In fact, they were very successful because of the surprise of getting ashore, and of course that's the most important thing.
And what time was it?
Did you launch the attack?
You know, I don't remember.
I wasn't in that initial assault.
That was the first brigade.
My brigade, the second brigade that I was with, came, as a matter of fact, several days later because the mission of that squadron was a reconnaissance in force, if that means anything to you.
No, what does that mean?
That means go in there and find out what's there and be prepared to pull off after you determine it and come back.
Well, this was a squadron of about 500 men with Brigadier General Chase in command.
He was commander of the 1st Brigade.
Squadron commander, Colonel Lobet.
But they did a beautiful job.
And when MacArthur came ashore, and they got ashore so beautifully, withstood that initial
counterattack so well.
That's when they took most of those casualties after the Japanese had time to react.
General MacArthur came ashore and said, hold on.
We're going to just stay here and clear up this whole series of islands and we'll send you reinforcements.
So then they sent the rest of the division in.
Now, our particular...
So you went in with artillery?
I went in with the 2nd Brigade, with the 6th 1st Field Artillery Battalion, and we had the 8th Regiment in that assault, the 8th Regiment of Cavalry, and the 7th.
But now we went in on the opposite side of the island,
These first assaults, well, it was mainly to envelop the enemy that remained there, take the pressure off of the 5th Cavalry.
And then coming in, there was one, there were two little islands, there was a ring of islands that joined, hooked up Los Negros Island
with the main island of Manus, almost hooked it up.
It was very open on the end.
We came in between the first and second island, away from Los Negros.
No problem.
Very narrow channel there between those two.
And the cavalry assaulted.
We came ashore and set up to support artillery.
It was just a short time and not very heavy fighting before the two forces joined up.

And so then it was a matter of simply consolidating on Los Negros and then after that the division operated to clean up Los Negros Island, this string of islands, and then later go on to the big Manus Island.
Now Manus Island became a major neighbor base after we took it.
In fact, I guess that was the biggest naval base away from Hawaii and away from the United States.
One little interesting detail, we later occupied the island that was on our right as we came in that channel for that invasion.
And as a matter of fact, we set our battalion up
in positions there to support the assault on Manus Island, the big island.
Where the airfield was stationed.
Well, the airfield was on Los Negros, but the naval base was built.
There was a beautiful harbor there, Seattle Harbor.
The Japs had a minor little naval facility there, but it became a major U.S. naval base.
Anyway, once we got on that island, that tip that we passed by had two naval guns on it.
Nobody saw when we went in there.
And nobody fired at you?
And nobody fired at us.
Oh, why?
Were the Japanese?
I'll never know because, of course, we had to invade that little island and there were Japanese on it, but not a lot.
Were they out of ammunition?
No.
We had one of them shooting.
Our executive officer, our service battery, had one of those guns shooting within two hours after we got on there.
And we shot their ammunition.
over in support of our troops.
Why they shot, I'm sure, why they didn't shoot when we came in there, obviously, our headquarters had reason to order them not to.
I don't know what it was.
What about that airstrip?
Did you have any problems taking it?
Were there any airplanes there?
No, there were no problems.
No airplanes by that time?
Had they been destroyed by our?
There were no airplanes there.
The only problem resulted in the Japs trying to counterattack and trying to take it back, trying to knock our troops off.
But it was put into operation very promptly.
The usual pattern was they'd send a CB's unit in there, you know, and get it going.
And they'd build a steel-reinforced runway?
You know, I believe it was, I don't recall whether that was rebuilt.
Now, we had to improve it, but later we were running B-24s off of it, so it had to be improved considerably.
But whether it was concrete or asphalt, I'm not sure.
I just don't remember.
Because they had those big steel planks that they used to put together.
I'm sure we used that.
I think probably what it was was a light asphalt with those, what do we call those steel, they had a name.
By the inventor's name, I guess it was.
Perforated steel.
In other words, in your first assault, you didn't take very many casualties.
Looking at the division as a whole, no.
In that initial squadron, they took quite a few.
But not in yours.
What were your feelings after you landed, after you realized that you made it?
Well, I think we all felt this is the first test, and we passed it, and we had a lot of confidence, self-confidence, a lot of confidence in our units.
This thing, of course,
The ugly part of these campaigns come in the so-called cleaning them out, cleanup operations.
And were there many on this island?
Were there many cleanup operations?
Yes, there were, because most of the troops, after they failed in that counterattack, tried to pull back and evade our attacks.
But they still were good at setting up ambushes, and occasionally we'd hit a tough position where they were ordered to stand.
There weren't an awful lot of them there.
It's just tedious doing it, and it's such a sweaty, tough hacking job through that jungle for those guys that have to go up there and be the forward troops in it.
Our job was to try to
kill as many Japanese and dominate much terrain with firepower and save as many lives and as much sweat as we could.
Eventually, of course, the infantry's got to take it, but there was a lot of satisfaction being a direct support artilleryman because that team became so close and those troops relied so much on us.
And I never saw such greater dedication to anything than the typical

our tournament realizing they're dependent on us we're here because of them you know then they're very effective and firepower we can get into greater discussions on this but we in this nation have been fortunate to have the means to afford sure vast superiority in firepower
That has saved us more lives than strategy or good tactics or anything else, in my opinion.
But, of course, I'm heavily oriented.
Not just artillery, but air support, naval support, the whole thing.
We used a lot of naval support in World War II in the Pacific and relied upon it.
That was our long-range artillery that in Europe would have been in the form of Corps and Army artillery.
Our Corps Army artillery was pretty scarce the way we operated in the Pacific in those years.
So as far as casualties were concerned, the infantry took the run in the casualties and not the artillery.
The artillery in that war was not subjected to the casualty means that our people in Europe were.
the Japanese very seldom brought artillery to bear on us.
And we, the artillery on our side, is the first target of the artillery of the enemy because we're so effective with ours.
Okay, well then let's go on to the next campaign.
This lasted from March 1944 until about when did you?
We invaded Lady Island in October.
in October of 1944.
Right, and at Lady Golf were you part of the naval battle which was the largest naval battle of the Second World War?
We were very much aware of it.
Were you out on a ship?
No, we were ashore at the time.
You see this naval battle occurred several days after we got ashore and after we'd assaulted the island of Lady.
And we were inland, I would say, we were several miles inland when this battle occurred.
The first sign to us was that our division headquarters ceased to send naval intelligence down to us.
And we routinely, the Navy would send the Army its intelligence.
It would send in basically where the main elements of the fleet were,
and intelligence on the enemy, and that just stopped.
Well, I guess initially nobody thought much about it.
Then we started getting propaganda leaflets.
The airplanes would, the jet planes would
started showing up.
And they'd fly over and drop leaflets?
In some numbers.
And that's the first time that had ever happened to us.
Well, of course, we realized that we went up there without any land-based aircraft, no Air Force support, because we had to get that airfield at Tacloban before they could come in.
We had only Navy carrier support.
And the main thing we wanted them to do was keep those Jap airplanes off of us and provide close air support.
Sure.
So, yes, they dropped during the early stages of that battle, as it turned out, they dropped leaflets.
I remember one of General MacArthur's statements of his strategy was that he would leapfrog back to the Philippines and leave many of the Japanese unchallenged Japanese formations.
But it leads them to wither on the vine.
You remember reading that?
Well, they dropped leaflets saying we were going to wither on the vine.
Well, it was never very seriously taken, but it did alert us to the fact that they were going to try to pull something off.
But the real evidence of the battle and that it was not all in our favor came when the US Naval
aircraft came into the Tacloban strip to land because it didn't have a carrier to land on.
And I mean, they were stacking in there and some of them were shot up and crash landing.
It was a mess.
But also, most of them, of course, got down safely.
But they had, I really, I don't suppose I ever knew how many.
But later, it was clear that a number of those carriers had been disabled.
And we had a heck of a lot of aircraft on that airfield just after he was taken.
It wasn't ready for him.
Of course, you can land a Navy plane on a dime, practically.
So then we were aware and then started getting information that there was a serious naval battle.
But we were not informed on how it went or how the opposing forces deployed or anything until it was over.
I'll say this.
I say we.
I think this was a typical outlook.

We had so much confidence in the U.S. Navy, even though they were a little bit short in MacArthur's territory because, you know, so much of the Navy was roaming the vast areas of the sea toward Japan.
But we had such confidence in them that we really weren't worried about it too much.
one scene there before the naval battle showed up that tends to give you confidence.
The enemy did make an effort to bomb our beach, our ships on the beach and to bomb our troop formations right after we landed and assaulted and for the next few days before this battle started.
I remember I was marching the battalion down a road moving position and
this whole formation of Japanese bombers and fighters approached and six little Navy Hellcats flew in and one by one just knocked them down.
It just looked like a shooting gallery.
Really?
It was the most amazing piece of air action that I saw in the whole war.
Six of them.
They couldn't defend themselves?
They couldn't match those.
The Zero fighter, they had a few to protect that bunch of bombers.
It never got to that beach area, by the way.
There was nothing wrong with the Zero for maneuverability and so forth as a fighter, but our people just must have been better, a lot better.
And they knocked...
I forget how many planes were in that formation, but I'm talking about probably 12 or 16, something like that.
Well, you know, we just stood there admiring this.
We just stopped to watch it.
Did you cheer?
Oh, yeah.
You thought it was a football game.
You'd hear the troops.
But anyway, everything the Navy had done, they were in such close support of us all the way from Australia, including training in Australia.
We had great confidence.
We never realized how serious that battle was until it was all over.
And the Navy had acquitted itself beautifully.
By this time, the Japanese were starting to use the Kamikazes.
Did you hear anything about them?
The kamikazes, we heard about them, but they were not a big factor in our operation down in the Philippines.
Where they became real serious was when we were approaching Japan more closely, say Okinawa and Saipan and so forth.
Then is when they really, as I recall, came into play.

And you can't criticize the people for that kamikaze outlook in a way you admire them, but of course the difference in the way we would do it and the way they did it, we put more value on the human life than they did.
As far as wasting the airplanes is concerned, my gosh, look what we do when we send a missile off now.
cost of money.
That doesn't bother us, it's the life that bothers us.
Now what were some of the problems that lay to you, military problems?
Well, I'm not sure I can give you a good critique, but I can give you, from my small point of view, I was
second in command of a battalion, which means that our battalion was in direct support of a cavalry regiment.
Usually it was the 8th Cavalry Regiment.
We tied into the division artillery headquarters, which was the fire support coordination headquarters for the entire division, whether it be artillery or naval gunfire
close air support.
So the artillery did have good communication and information on what's going on.
So I could still visualize what's going on a little further away than my own outfit.
The biggest problem in the later campaign was terrain, and that's often the case in war.
And later we'll get into the 1st Cavalry Division.
There's an air mobile, air assault, helicopter maneuvered division, which freed us from the terrain.
There was a very poor road system in Laney.
And of course, we were there in the rainy season.
Getting from point A to point B, quite apart from maneuver required, was a problem.
The prime mover for our 105 Howitzers and Arbitatins and the others, too, was a little Caterpillar tractor.
The vehicle for carrying cargo, such as ammunition and supplies, was the one-ton trailer hooked behind Caterpillar tractors.
battery-sized unit had a little Caterpillar tractor with a bulldozer blade on it, a bulldozer.
And that's how we licked the terrain.
Gee whiz.
And you really couldn't move large numbers of wheeled vehicles until the rains let up, you know, after you'd had a certain amount of it.
until some of the roads were improved.
Of course, that was too vast an undertaking to support an operation in motion.
So I would say the terrain was the major problem.
How did you move your artillery?
Pulled it with the caterpillar tractors.
We could go anywhere with those caterpillar tractors, with a bulldozer to help.
I don't think we had any real serious problems in accomplishing our missions other than the terrain.
I think one of our great challenges, and this is always a challenge in war and a much sought after area of advantage, was intelligence.
But that was a problem from the word go with the Japanese because it was just
a very difficult thing to take a prisoner.
And that's your best source of intelligence.
And their discipline was good.
Ordinarily, you'll get, and we did get some, but you'd get documents off the bodies of casualties, enemy casualties.
But the prisoner was denied us.
The general denied your observation.
And in those days, we didn't have this
Marvelous electronic means of intelligence now, literally listening to the enemy.
So I'd say that was the greatest challenge.
Did you take any Japanese prisoners?
Some.
Did they ever talk?
Not many, and not many who really knew much.
I recall that going back to our first operation, our division commander, every commander wants
became so upset that he wasn't getting any prisoners that he personally went to every battalion commander deployed and ordered him, get me a prisoner.
Most of them got him one.
But this wasn't so much that we were not going to take prisoners.
It wasn't our rules.
It was the Japanese rules in two forms.
One, they had fought the war, and we'd been told this by everybody, the Marines, and everybody else had been exposed to them, that they're going to fight until they die.
And I believe this, that it was said, and I believe it, that they were ordered, if they didn't die fighting, that they commit suicide.
And we know that a number of them did that.
So it just resulted in bursting in casualties.
There weren't many that you could get your hands on in the first place.
And when your enemy is going to fight to the death, you're probably going to kill him, because you're probably going to have to kill him before you can get your hands on him.
I guess we were as brutal as they were, but it was not abolition, is what I'm saying.
And did any of your men become their prisoners?
There was only one known incident where we had some people taken prisoners.
our own troops, and this was a matter of them being overrun.
Many of our soldiers said they'd save the last bullet for themselves, but I think when you get in the heat of the battle, it's just not very likely.
But in that particular incident, we recovered the soldiers, but they were all dead but one, and they were recovered by immediate counterattack.
Maybe it doesn't make
since, and the higher commander never ordered it.

But if anybody got trapped, you know, if you had to fall back or if you got pushed off to the flank and somebody wasn't counted for, the local commander, if he had the strength, he would just automatically counterattack to go get that man.
It was just sort of a, what is it, an unwritten practice.
I admired them for that.
Probably cost more casualties.
Maybe it doesn't, you know, maybe it doesn't make much sense, but that's the way they did it.
That's the only case that I know where we lost prisoners.
And then the Japanese murder.
But the Japanese murder, except one was not killed.
Why wasn't he killed?
Well, he'd been wounded.
Oh.
They thought, I guess they'd done him in, but
Was there a lot of hatred then?
Oh yes, of course.
That was the nature of that war.
And I must say that our people all hated the North Vietnamese almost as much.
You hate all your enemies when you're about to kill each other.
Sure.
There's no other way.
so-called gentleman's war that was fought in Europe, I doubt if you were to find yourself in the company on the front line that you'd see much gentlemanly about it.
The generals can be courteous and all that, but not the guys up there that got a beat on each other.
Do you want to take a break?
Okay.
